page_analysis.text_content:
Basements
&
Excavated
features

Floor area regulations
are intended to address
the building mass and
the appearance of the
streetscape. Therefore,
if basement area is
below grade and does
not contribute to the
apparent mass of a
building, that area,
even if it is habitable,
need not be included in
the total floor area.

Code sections
Page 40
18.12.090 (a, b, & c)
Page 41
18.12.090 (c)
Page 43
18.12.090 (c) (1)
Page 44
18.12.090 (c) (2)

Basement standards

• May not be located in special flood hazard areas.
• May not extend beyond building footprint.
• May not encroach into required yards, except where
  main dwelling is permitted to extend into rear yard.

FAR
Basements (even habitable ones) do
not count as floor area if first floor
is no more than 3' above grade.

Fig 35 Basement & grade

Excavated features

There are two types of excavated features:
• Light wells and stairwells
• Below-grade patios

FAR
Excavation will not affect grade or
measurement of floor area if stan-
dards are met (see pages 42 and 43).

Fig 36 Excavated feature & grade

A: distance between top of first floor
and grade if excavation meets the
size/dimensioinal limits described in
Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

B: distance between top of first
floor and grade if excavated
features exceed the
size/dimensioinal limits described
in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

Top of first floor

Basement
Excavated
feature

Grade if excavated features
meet standards described in
Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

Grade if excavated features
exceed standards described in
Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

40

visual_elements.description: Figure 35: A cross-section diagram illustrating 'Basement & grade'. It shows a section of ground with a hatched pattern representing earth. There is a horizontal line indicating 'grade' and a hatched area below it, representing a basement. The diagram depicts the relationship between the ground level and the basement.

Figure 36: A cross-section diagram illustrating 'Excavated feature & grade'. It shows a partial side view of a building with a basement and an excavated feature. The ground is represented by a hatched pattern. A vertical line labeled 'Basement' extends downwards from the building's foundation. Adjacent to it, another vertical line labeled 'Excavated feature' extends downwards, indicating an excavation. There are two arrows labeled 'A' and 'B' indicating vertical distances. 'A' points from the 'Top of first floor' to the 'Grade' line where excavated features meet standards. 'B' points from the 'Top of first floor' to a lower 'Grade' line where excavated features exceed standards. The diagram visually explains the definitions of 'A' and 'B' in relation to the top of the first floor and different grade levels for excavated features.

technical_specifications.parameter: Maximum height of first floor above grade for FAR exclusion (basements)

sections: Floor area regulations are intended to address the building mass and the appearance of the streetscape. Therefore, if basement area is below grade and does not contribute to the apparent mass of a building, that area, even if it is habitable, need not be included in the total floor area.
May not be located in special flood hazard areas.
May not extend beyond building footprint.
May not encroach into required yards, except where main dwelling is permitted to extend into rear yard.
Basements (even habitable ones) do not count as floor area if first floor is no more than 3' above grade.
There are two types of excavated features:
Excavation will not affect grade or measurement of floor area if standards are met (see pages 42 and 43).
A: distance between top of first floor and grade if excavation meets the size/dimensioinal limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.
B: distance between top of first floor and grade if excavated features exceed the size/dimensioinal limits described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.
Grade if excavated features meet standards described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.
Grade if excavated features exceed standards described in Figs 39-40 on pp. 42-43.

additional_notes: Page number '40' is located at the bottom left corner of the page.
